title: Opinion: As NCAA changes image, likeness rule, the delaying will go until government intervenes
text:
CLOSE NCAA approves compensation for image, likeness AP, AP

Shoved against the wall by legislation, lawsuits and evolving public opinion, the NCAA would nonetheless have us think it is backing down out of benevolence.

The concession statement issued Tuesday by the NCAA Board of Governors reads as if it were written by the propaganda minister of a surrounded, surrendering dictatorship. It emphasizes the association’s “continuing efforts to support college athletes,” while conspicuously omitting any reference to the persuasive pressures that have been applied by California, Congress and the courts.

It is, of course, a crock. To the extent the NCAA is relaxing its restrictions on an athlete’s ability to “benefit” from his or her name, likeness and image (NIL) – and that extent remains undetermined – it is not doing so because of inalienable rights or because it’s the right thing to do but because the organization’s heavy hand has been forced by the law, by lawmakers and by the inexorable tide of history.

NCAA president Mark Emmert. (Photo: Robert Deutsch-USA TODAY Sports)

"There’s no question the legislative efforts in Congress and various states has been a catalyst to change," NCAA President Mark Emmert acknowledged Tuesday in Atlanta. "It’s clear that schools and the presidents are listening and have heard loud and clear that everyone agrees this is an area that needs to be addressed."

More: If college athletes could profit off their marketability, how much would they be worth? In some cases, millions

It’s clear, too, that NCAA actions concerning athlete welfare are invariably reactions. The organization overseeing college sports in this country gives ground grudgingly, typically when outflanked, while clinging to the archaic concept of amateurism as a means to preserve its cash flow and control. In an era of skyrocketing coaching salaries, bloated staffing levels and static scholarship limits, the NCAA’s concern for the plight of student athletes appears to be more often stated than sincere.

When NCAA board chairman Michael V. Drake, president of Ohio State, says, “We must embrace change to provide the best possible experience for college athletes,” the appropriate response is either a giggle or a guffaw.

The NCAA embraces change as if it were a cactus. Even now, as federal and state governments prod the organization toward meaningful reforms, foot-dragging continues to frustrate measures that properly belong on the fast track. Tuesday’s unanimous vote to allow athletes’ NIL rights was conditioned on those rights being exercised “in a manner consistent with the collegiate model.”

Whatever that means.

To former Duke basketball star Jay Bilas, an attorney and ESPN analyst, what that most likely means is, “We’re not allowing ANYTHING.”

“‘Collegiate model’ is another made-up term with no meaning,” Bilas tweeted. “It’s just, ‘Everything is pro, only the players are restricted.’”

Furthermore, any forthcoming rules governing NIL transactions are expected to “facilitate fair and balanced competition,” prevent compensation for performance or participation and “prohibit inducements to select, remain at, or transfer to a specific institution.”

In short, the NCAA is ceding control only slightly, while establishing parameters and a process for bylaw revision sure to spawn more subcommittees and additional delay. Though any organization with 1,115 member institutions and three distinct divisions is bound to be a bit unwieldy, the NCAA has a knack for turning fundamental questions into filibusters.

Happily, however, stall tactics are of limited utility against motivated adversaries with superior power. While the NCAA operates at a significant advantage against aggrieved students with finite eligibility, it will have a harder time running out the clock on California or on the federal government, should any of the pending NIL bills pass.

Should it fail to move fast or far enough, the NCAA would risk losing some of its self-governing authority to politicians. Given the billions its member schools generate through sports, and that NIL payments would presumably come from third parties and not university funds, this would be a bad time to misread the room.

In its “continuing efforts to support college athletes,” the NCAA can be counted on to consider what works best for the NCAA. That’s not benevolence, but pragmatism.
